one bound for Wuhu where we

Chinese have
Chinking, a town just upstream from the boom which the
stretched across the Yangisze to keep the Jap fleet out of the
Our Captain and his first mate - both Britishers - say the boom is an effective
river.
bar to navigation.
It is composed of old hulks filled with stones and sunk side
by side clear across the river.
Below the boom an extensive system of mines makes
it dangerous to even approach the boom.
The small Chinese boats can get around
the boom through a series of canals and are busy carrying Shanghai cargo around
the boom, which cargo is delivered then to English boats which carry it in either
direction to or away from Shanghai.
Friday, Oct. 29th.
so you see I'm not suffering from insomnia.
Went to bed at 9 P.M. and didn't wake up until 8 A.
This morning there is a cold wind blow-
ing from the north.
We have just left Wuhu and' are due at Nanking about noon.
weather is bad - whioh is good - because the Japs can't bomb with a low ceiling.
If they fly low the enti-aircraft guns shoot them down and if they fly high they
can't see Nenking because there is a solid overeast at about 3000 feet. Also since
International p essure has been exerted against indiscriminate bombing that type of
attack has been practiced only against cities and towns where there are no influen-
tial foreigners.
Sat. Oct. 30th. We arrived Nanking without incident.
The boat docked
about three miles upstream from the Nanking Bund and we transferred to a tug which
brought us (standing in the Rain on front deck) to the dock. There we hired the
most disreputable looking old Ford taxi
and set out for the Americen Embassy.
main drag (Chung Shen Road) is lined with bomb shelters. Otherwise the capital
quiet and untouched by war as before the present hostilities began.
Several bomb sears have since been pointed out to me but craters have been filled
signs of damage are discernible.
been hit though many have been the target of air raids.
None of the large public buildings has
We are living at the
American Embassy with Mr. Peck who very kindly invited us to live with him during
Last night Mr. Peck had a dinner party with Ambassador
Johnson, a Dr. and Mrs. Hershberg and their twenty year old daughter.
very charming Germans who all p oke excellent English.
Dr. Hershberg is a famous
surgeon who has done some remarkable operations and is helping tremendously in
the present Chinese hospital management.
It is suspected that he left a good prac-
tice in Germany to aw id persecution by Hittlerites. After dinner we played
AGPOLISE PIOS
